content:
The number of accidents caused by mining and construction has quadrupled since 2004

THE SLUDGY water in Brumadinho is receding, but the body count is rapidly rising. On January 25th a tailings dam at a mine in Brazil collapsed, burying at least 60 people under millions of tonnes of mud and leaving nearly 300 missing. The final death toll could be the highest caused by a failed mining dam since 1966, when a flood at a Bulgarian lead quarry killed nearly 500 people.

Unfortunately, these types of accidents are becoming more common. Mining firms use Tailings dams to contain the mucky residue that they produce when digging up metals, and often build them from the waste itself. According to World Mine Tailings Failures (WMTF), a database of accidents caused by such structures, the tally of disasters has increased roughly in line with the amount of ore that miners have extracted from the ground. Between 2008 and 2017 there were 13 “very serious” incidents around the world (according to an index based on deaths and sludge displaced), as many as occurred between 1948 and 1977.

Even as the mining industry has expanded, it has made little progress in preventing these tragedies. The Brumadinho dam was owned by Vale, Brazil’s largest mining firm, which also co-owned a dam in Mariana that failed in 2015, killing 19 people. Vale made regular inspections at Brumadinho, but failed to spot any structural weaknesses. Because companies are struggling to keep their dams in order, the academics who compile WMTF expect 19 very serious incidents to occur between 2018 and 2027.

Mining firms are not the only culprits. Melanie Froude and Dave Petley, two geographers at the University of Sheffield, have recorded a dramatic increase in deadly landslides caused by construction and illegal hill cutting (which generally occurs when people dig up clay for building houses). When added together with mining, these industrial processes caused roughly four times as many incidents and deaths in 2016 as they did in 2004. Most of them happened in China and South Asia, where the use of land has changed more quickly than safety standards have improved.

The climate also plays a role. Dams and buildings are more likely to collapse after heavy rainfall. For every landslide that is triggered primarily by an industrial failure, four more are precipitated by the weather. Yet despite a rapidly changing global climate, there is little evidence that rain-induced tragedies are becoming more common. The increasing number of deadly incidents seems to be driven by shoddy human endeavours.

研究人员们表示他们每隔一天导入小核RNA和信使RNA,就能够诱导细胞持续一周产生重新编码蛋白质。

ex: n. 触发器；（枪的）扳机；（尤指引发不良反应或发展的）起因；引爆器

eg2: to pull/squeeze the trigger
扣扳机
He kept his finger on the trigger.
他的手指一直勾着扳机。

nuclear triggers
核引爆器
Nuts can trigger off a violent allergic reaction.
坚果可以引起严重的过敏反应。
to trigger an alarm
触发警报器

Title: Deadly landslides with man-made causes are becoming more common

paperStatistics.title: Deadly landslides with man-made causes are becoming more common
paperStatistics.desc: The number of accidents caused by mining and construction has quadrupled since 2004
